title: Stress
description: Learning to manage daily stress and develop healthy coping mechanisms.
welcomeMessage: Take control of your stress levels. Learn practical techniques to manage everyday pressures and build resilience.

cards.introduction: Sometimes the body signals before we realize we are stressed. Let’s start with that.
questions: How do you feel stress in your body right now (location, level from 1 to 10)?
What was happening shortly before these sensations appeared?
cards.recommendation: Throughout the week, notice and write down bodily signals of stress. Why: this helps track early markers of overload.

cards.introduction: Sleep is the first to suffer. Stress rarely goes away if we don’t rest.
questions: How often do you wake up at night or feel tired in the morning?
What thoughts or worries keep you from relaxing before bed?
cards.recommendation: Create a “shutdown ritual”: 30 minutes before bed — no screens, write down 3 good things from the day. Why: restores biorhythm and improves sleep quality.
cards.mechanism: Regulation of the wake-sleep cycle lowers cortisol levels.

cards.introduction: You don’t have to be productive 24/7. Even machines overheat.
questions: What expectations do you place on yourself during the day?
What is unrealistic in these expectations?
cards.recommendation: Choose 1 task for the day that you will consciously “not do.” Why: you learn to allow pauses and reality.

cards.introduction: Stress thoughts are often fast, sharp, and blaming. Time to slow them down.
questions: What thoughts usually appear when you are overloaded?
What would you say to a friend if he thought this way about himself?
cards.recommendation: Find 1 thought and 1 alternative perspective on it. Repeat this exercise 3 times a week. Why: you train self-support.

cards.introduction: Stress often turns the future into a catastrophe. But it’s just a scenario.
questions: What negative forecast do you often replay in your head?
What is the probability it will come true? And what are the alternatives?
cards.recommendation: Write down your fear dividing it into “real” and “possible.” Why: this reduces automatic catastrophizing.

cards.introduction: When everything collapses, it’s important to understand what is really under control.
questions: What can you not change in your current situation?
And what is within your sphere of influence?
cards.recommendation: Divide everything that worries you into 2 columns: “can influence” and “cannot.” Work only with the first. Why: this reduces anxious brain activity.
cards.mechanism: Focusing efforts within the control zone.

cards.introduction: Stress affects attention. We lose focus, and everything seems even worse.
questions: When was the last time you noticed you just ‘zoned out’?
What happened 10–15 minutes before that?
cards.recommendation: Once a day, take a 3-minute breathing observation pause. Why: this trains focus and resilience.
cards.mechanism: Mindfulness lowers cortisol and switches off ‘autopilot.’

questions: What little things have irritated you especially strongly lately?
What else might this be related to besides current events?
cards.recommendation: Arrange a ‘day of silence’ — turn off notifications and minimize external stimuli. Why: reducing stimuli lowers sensory overload.

cards.introduction: Your body is not the enemy. It knows how to release tension.
questions: What physical actions help you relieve stress (movement, breathing, water)?
When was the last time you used one of them?
cards.recommendation: Choose 1 method (e.g., ‘box breathing’ 4-4-4-4) and use it twice a day for 5 days. Why: you build a self-regulation skill.
cards.mechanism: Influence on the sympathetic nervous system.

cards.introduction: You have the right to stop. Even for 15 minutes.
questions: What would you like to do right now if you had no obligations?
What prevents you from doing it, at least partially?
cards.recommendation: During the week, take a 15-minute ‘reset’ during the day: silence, tea, window, walk. Why: restores contact with yourself and reduces emotional tension.
